replies.author: aivinog1

replies.bodyText:
Ah yes, there is a timing issue. I dove into it a bit.
We register the broadcaster as a failure listener using the actor scheduler, but at the moment we call this, we have (in the line before) already activated the actor scheduler which is busy starting the partition. During this start, the health has already been determined (multiple times even) and each failure listener is notified when it changed. Directly after the start, the scheduler does the next task (adding the broadcaster) and after that the health doesn't change any more. So the broadcaster is never informed.
So, I see 2 solutions:

when a new listener is added to the partition, check the health and update the listener accordingly.
pass the broadcaster to the partition in the constructor

After discussing with @deepthidevaki solution 1 has our preference, since this pattern is already applied in other places as well.

timeline.bodyText:
Please use ZeebePartition.getHealthStatus() to determine the current health.
this.zeebePartitionHealth only contains the health that the ZeebePartition can control (e.g. installation failure), while there are also other components that may fail, like the log stream and the stream processor. Each of these is a different component, and they are all registered in the CriticalComponentsHealthMonitor, which is used to determine the health status when you just call ZeebePartition.getHealthStatus().

You can actually just use the healthMonitor (see L45), and stub the healthstatus. Something like:
